title: What is the really old font used in old documents (typewriter font?)
content:
What is the font that is used in really old books and it looks very dark and nice?

Here are a few examples:

[http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online\_books/declaration/images/fig8.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417182342/http:/www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/declaration/images/fig8.jpg "http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online\_books/declaration/images/fig8.jpg")

[http://www.cems.ox.ac.uk/images/big/PARADISE\_LOST5.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417182342/http:/www.cems.ox.ac.uk/images/big/PARADISE_LOST5.jpg "http://www.cems.ox.ac.uk/images/big/PARADISE\_LOST5.jpg")

[http://www.sullivanpress.com/images/RevImages/shamela.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417182342/http:/www.sullivanpress.com/images/RevImages/shamela.jpg "http://www.sullivanpress.com/images/RevImages/shamela.jpg")

[http://www.sullivanpress.com/images/RevImages/fencing.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417182342/http:/www.sullivanpress.com/images/RevImages/fencing.jpg "http://www.sullivanpress.com/images/RevImages/fencing.jpg")
author: Axmann

comments.content: Chase: The images you've provided were probably not printed using the same font. The general category under which those designs fall is Old Style. (Although 1 or 2 of them may be Transitional). I don't know Type history as well as many of the other folks on these forums, but I'd wager that your sample from Common Sense was printed with a font of Caslon.
